t Tue, 23 Oct 2007 12:14:54 -0000,
"nt_bdr" <nt_bdr@...> wrote:
>
> I used Heretrix to crawl one of the websites that has a lot of dynamic
> urls. I have read that crawlers typically have problems crawling
> dynamic  URLs. I don't find these URL's in Google's index. But
> Heretrix has been able to crawl these URLs. Because dynamically
> generated pages don't actually exist until a user selects the
> variable(s) that generate them, I am curious to know how Heretrix is
> able to crawl them.
> Example:
> http://autos.aol.com/autos_compare?v1=9210|USB80TOC161C0&v2=9287|USB80CHC212C0&v3=9736|USB80HOC021D0&v4=9208|USB80MAC171E0

As long as the information necessary to generate the URL exists in the
html, Heritrix will tend to fill out forms, generate urls from
javascript, etc., in the interest of fetching all available web
content.

For example, the example you use is enormously complex javascript, but
all the values for generating the above URL are in the HTML or
javascript. Think of the difference between a user filling in a form
with the make as a completely freeform field, entering “Toyota”, and
the user being given a choice, “Toyota” or “Ford”. If the user is
given a choice, then Heritrix knows what the possible form values are.
If it is completely free-form, then Heritrix cannot know what could be
a good input, & will not generate new urls to fetch.

best,
Erik
;; Erik Hetzner, California Digital Library
;; gnupg key id: 1024D/01DB07E3
